title: How the US-China trade conflict could cost the eurozone $25 billion
text:
According to Spanish news site El Mundo, the consequences of the ongoing trade war between the US and China could have far-reaching consequences that affect many countries; not just the two nations in question.

The Bank of Spain has forecast that the impact of the US-China trade conflict could cost the eurozone somewhere in the way of $25 billion (€23 billion).

As well as a serious impact on the eurozone, the trade battle could end up reducing the world GDP by 0.25% or roughly $278 billion.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.

Since last year, both China and the US and have been embroiled in a diplomatic feud with no real end in sight — a feud that's resulted in repeated hikes in import tariffs that affect all manner of goods.

According to a report by El Mundo, May 2019 saw the respective countries ratchet up the trade war even further with additional tariffs, affecting total imports of Chinese goods and nearly 75% of US products.

However, the two nations aren't the only ones affected by the intensifying trade war.

A China Shipping Line container ship passing through the Port of Los Angeles in California. David McNew/Getty Images

The trade war isn't just damaging economies of the two countries in question; it's forecast to wreak collateral havoc on European growth too.

Read more: The US journalist detained for 544 days in Iran warns: 'Trump's foreign policy is misguided and under-informed'

According to the Bank of Spain writing for El Mundo, the eurozone's GDP will experience a 0.2% dip — equating to approximately €23 billion (or roughly $25 billion) — due to how heavily it relies on open trade.

Donald Trump and Xi Jinping. Carlos Barria/Reuters

In total, the trade war may eventually knock out a substantial 0.25% from the world's GDP, working out to approximately $278 billion.

Read more: A UN Secretary General adviser called Donald Trump a 'psychopath' for suggesting a return to coal power

With a growth loss of 0.38%, China would take the biggest hit, according to the report — on the other hand, El Mundo's report suggests growth levels in the US would fall by 0.26%.

El Mundo also suggested there could be "significant" adverse effects that may increase the first risk of investment.
description: The consequences of the ongoing trade war could have far-reaching consequences for many countries; not just the US and China.
